title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: Corrected Covered Area (CCA) quantifies overlap studies included multiple systematic reviews. high CCA value indicates high degree overlap, suggesting potential redundancy evidence synthesis. vignette explains: formula CCA compute CCA R visualize study overlap using heatmap

title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: CCA calculated : CCA=N−rr(c−1)×100 CCA = \frac{N - r}{r (c - 1)} \times 100 : - NN = total number study occurrences across reviews - rr = number unique included studies - cc = number systematic reviews

title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: use example dataset 5 studies across 5 systematic reviews:
code: library(tidyverse) library(junoR)    # Example dataset data <- tibble(   study = rep(paste0("Study_", 1:5), times = 5),   review = rep(paste0("Review_", 1:5), each = 5),   status = c("included", "included", "ineligible", NA, NA,               NA, "included", NA, "excluded", NA,               "included", NA, "included", "excluded", "ineligible",               "included", "excluded", "included", "excluded", NA,               NA, "included", "ineligible", NA, "excluded") )  # View the data print(data) ## # A tibble: 25 × 3 ##    study   review   status     ##    <chr>   <chr>    <chr>      ##  1 Study_1 Review_1 included   ##  2 Study_2 Review_1 included   ##  3 Study_3 Review_1 ineligible ##  4 Study_4 Review_1 NA         ##  5 Study_5 Review_1 NA         ##  6 Study_1 Review_2 NA         ##  7 Study_2 Review_2 included   ##  8 Study_3 Review_2 NA         ##  9 Study_4 Review_2 excluded   ## 10 Study_5 Review_2 NA         ## # ℹ 15 more rows

title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: use cca_heatmap() function compute CCA: means 42% included studies redundant.
code: # Run the function result <- cca_heatmap(data)  # Print CCA result result$CCA ## [1] 41.66667

title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: function also generates heatmap showing studies included reviews:  produces heatmap : Green = included studies Dark grey = excluded studies Orange = ineligible studies Light grey = missing data
code: # Generate heatmap result$plot

title: Corrected Covered Area (CCA)
text: Pieper, D., Antoine, S. L., Mathes, T., Neugebauer, E. ., & Eikermann, M. (2014). Systematic review finds overlapping reviews mentioned every overview. Journal Clinical Epidemiology, 67(4), 368–375. DOI: 10.1016/j.jclinepi.2013.11.007 Hedges, L. V., & Olkin, . (1988). Statistical Methods Meta-Analysis. Academic Press.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) probabilistic topic modelling algorithm used discover hidden topics collection documents. document represented mixture topics. topic represented mixture words. Example: analyse news articles, LDA might find topics like "Politics," "Sports," "Technology," characterised related words.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: LDA unsupervised method—doesn’t know topics , discovered topics may always align expect.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: Seeded LDA, provide seed words topic. helps guide topic formation process topics align meaningful categories. Example Use Case: analyzing scientific literature, may seed topics specific words: “Climate Change” → [“warming”, “carbon”, “emissions”] “Biodiversity” → [“species”, “habitat”, “conservation”]

title: An example seeded topic model
text: use textmineR package perform Seeded LDA.

title: An example seeded topic model
code: #install.packages("textmineR") #install.packages("tm")  # For text preprocessing  library(textmineR) library(tm)

title: An example seeded topic model
text: use small dataset articles. document separate text entry, want identify themes .
code: documents <- c(   "Climate change is causing rising temperatures and increasing emissions.",   "Renewable energy sources like solar and wind help reduce carbon footprint.",   "Biodiversity is under threat due to habitat destruction and pollution.",   "Technology companies invest in artificial intelligence and data science.",   "Deep learning and neural networks are advancing AI research." )

title: An example seeded topic model
text: LDA works best cleaned text. : Convert text lowercase Remove stopwords (e.g., “”, “”, “”) Remove punctuation Convert text document-term matrix (DTM)
code: # Create a corpus corpus <- Corpus(VectorSource(documents))  # Preprocess: Convert to lowercase, remove stopwords, remove punctuation corpus <- tm_map(corpus, content_transformer(tolower)) corpus <- tm_map(corpus, removeWords, stopwords("english")) corpus <- tm_map(corpus, removePunctuation)  # Create a document-term matrix (DTM) dtm <- CreateDtm(doc_vec = sapply(corpus, as.character),                   doc_names = paste0("doc", 1:length(documents)),                   ngram_window = c(1,2))  # Unigrams & bigrams

title: An example seeded topic model
text: guide model using seed words topic:
code: # Define seed words for topics seed_words <- list(   "climate_change" = c("climate", "warming", "carbon", "emissions"),   "biodiversity" = c("biodiversity", "species", "habitat", "pollution"),   "technology" = c("technology", "artificial", "intelligence", "data") )

previous_headings: 3. Seeded LDA Example in R > Step 4: Define Seed Words
title: An example seeded topic model
text: ensures LDA associates documents topics based expert knowledge. Otherwise, random words might define topics unexpected ways.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: train Seeded LDA model:
code: # Train Seeded LDA lda_model <- FitLdaModel(dtm = dtm,                           k = length(seed_words),  # Number of topics                          iterations = 500,                           burnin = 100,                          seed_words = seed_words)

previous_headings: 3. Seeded LDA Example in R > Step 5: Fit Seeded LDA Model
title: An example seeded topic model
text: k = length(seed_words): Number topics (based many seed word groups define). iterations = 500: Number updates model. burnin = 100: Initial iterations ignored better convergence.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: training, check topics dominate document: row = document column = topic.

title: An example seeded topic model
text: topic probability distribution words. document probability distribution topics. Words strongly define topics can extracted:
code: get_top_terms <- function(phi, num_words = 10) {   apply(phi, 1, function(topic) {     names(sort(topic, decreasing = TRUE))[1:num_words]   }) }  get_top_terms(lda_model$phi)  # Top words for each topic #>       t_1                       t_2                       #>  [1,] "advancing"               "advancing"               #>  [2,] "advancing_ai"            "advancing_ai"            #>  [3,] "ai"                      "ai"                      #>  [4,] "ai_research"             "ai_research"             #>  [5,] "artificial"              "artificial"              #>  [6,] "artificial_intelligence" "artificial_intelligence" #>  [7,] "biodiversity"            "biodiversity"            #>  [8,] "biodiversity_threat"     "biodiversity_threat"     #>  [9,] "carbon"                  "carbon"                  #> [10,] "carbon_footprint"        "carbon_footprint"        #>       t_3                       #>  [1,] "advancing"               #>  [2,] "advancing_ai"            #>  [3,] "ai"                      #>  [4,] "ai_research"             #>  [5,] "artificial"              #>  [6,] "artificial_intelligence" #>  [7,] "biodiversity"            #>  [8,] "biodiversity_threat"     #>  [9,] "carbon"                  #> [10,] "carbon_footprint"

title: An example seeded topic model
text: Feature |Standard LDA| Seeded LDA Topic Discovery |Unsupervised (random topics)| Semi-supervised (guided topics) Accuracy| Can noisy| aligned domain knowledge Flexibility| Fully data-driven| Requires predefined seed words Use Case| General topic discovery| expected topics

title: An example seeded topic model
text: expect specific topics want guide LDA results. don’t want topics random.

title: Using R to clean up text
text: working text data imported , example Excel, may encounter issues : Non-printable characters (e.g., zero-width spaces, control characters) Carriage returns (\r) line breaks (\n) Bullet points unwanted symbols document outlines common techniques cleaning text using R.

title: Using R to clean up text
code: library(stringr)

title: Using R to clean up text
text: Non-printable characters, ASCII control characters, can removed using iconv() str_replace_all().
code: clean_nonprintable <- function(text) {   text <- iconv(text, "latin1", "ASCII", sub = "") # Removes non-ASCII characters   text <- str_replace_all(text, "[^[:print:]]", "") # Removes other control characters   return(text) }  # Example test_text <- "Hello\u0007World!" clean_nonprintable(test_text) #> [1] "HelloWorld!"

what: Removing Carriage Returns and Line Breaks
title: Using R to clean up text
text: Excel often includes carriage returns (\r) new lines (\n) text data. can removed using gsub() str_replace_all().
code: clean_linebreaks <- function(text) {   text <- str_replace_all(text, "\r|\n", " ") # Replace with space   return(text) }  # Example test_text <- "This is line one.\r\nThis is line two." clean_linebreaks(test_text) #> [1] "This is line one.  This is line two."

title: Using R to clean up text
text: Bullet points special characters can removed using regular expressions.
code: clean_bullets <- function(text) {   text <- str_replace_all(text, "[•●▪▶✓✔]", "") # Remove common bullet points   return(text) }  # Example test_text <- "• Item one\n● Item two" clean_bullets(test_text) #> [1] " Item one\n Item two"

title: Using R to clean up text
text: can create single function applies cleaning steps.
code: clean_text <- function(text) {   text <- clean_nonprintable(text)   text <- clean_linebreaks(text)   text <- clean_bullets(text)   text <- str_trim(text) # Trim leading/trailing spaces   return(text) }  # Example test_text <- "• Item one\r\n● Item two with \u0007non-printable chars" clean_text(test_text) #> [1] "Item one Item two with non-printable chars"

title: Using R to clean up text
text: functions help standardise imported text, making easier process analyse R.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Matthew Grainger. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation

code: @Manual{,   title = {junoR: junoR},   author = {{Matthew Grainger}},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000}, }

title: junoR
text: R package shared functions evidence synthesis install package please run following code R:
code: install.packages("devtools") # if you don't have devtools installed devtools::install_github("Juno-Evidence-Alliance/junoR")# install the package from the github repository

what: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
text: function calculates Corrected Covered Area (CCA) set studies across systematic reviews generates heatmap study inclusion.

title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
code: cca_heatmap(data, show_plot = TRUE)

title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
text: data tibble dataframe columns: study (character): Study identifiers. review (character): Review identifiers. status (character): Study status, one c("included", "excluded", "ineligible", NA). show_plot Logical; TRUE, returns heatmap plot, otherwise CCA value.

title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
text: list : CCA (numeric): Corrected Covered Area value. plot (ggplot object): heatmap (show_plot = TRUE).

title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
text: Pieper, D., Antoine, S. L., Mathes, T., Neugebauer, E. ., & Eikermann, M. (2014). Systematic review finds overlapping reviews mentioned every overview. Journal Clinical Epidemiology, 67(4), 368–375. doi:10.1016/j.jclinepi.2013.11.007 Hedges, L. V., & Olkin, . (1988). Statistical Methods Meta-Analysis. Academic Press.

title: Calculate Corrected Covered Area (CCA) and Generate a Heatmap — cca_heatmap
code: library(tidyverse) #> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── #> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5 #> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1 #> ✔ ggplot2   3.5.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1 #> ✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1 #> ✔ purrr     1.0.4      #> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag() #> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors library(junoR) # Example dataset data <- tibble(   study = rep(paste0("Study_", 1:5), times = 5),   review = rep(paste0("Review_", 1:5), each = 5),   status = c("included", "included", "ineligible", NA, NA,              NA, "included", NA, "excluded", NA,              "included", NA, "included", "excluded", "ineligible",              "included", "excluded", "included", "excluded", NA,              NA, "included", "ineligible", NA, "excluded") )  # Run function result <- cca_heatmap(data) print(result$CCA) #> [1] 41.66667 print(result$plot)

what: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: function compares two blocks text (e.g., abstracts) using multiple similarity measures. supports Jaccard Similarity, Cosine Similarity, Levenshtein Distance, Longest Common Subsequence. function returns similarity score based chosen method.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
code: compare_texts(text1, text2)

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: text1 first text block compare. text2 second text block compare.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: numeric value representing similarity two text blocks.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: function compare two blocks text using various similarity measures. calculates similarity based Jaccard, Cosine Similarity, Levenshtein Distance, Longest Common Subsequence.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: function compares two blocks text using several different similarity measures. descriptions commonly used measures work:

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: Definition: Jaccard similarity measures proportion shared words two texts, ignoring word order. calculated : J(, B) = |∩ B| / |∪ B| : B sets unique words text. |∩ B| number words common texts. |∪ B| total number unique words across texts. Interpretation: Values range 0 (words common) 1 (identical texts). Higher values indicate word overlap, measure account word frequency order.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: Definition: Cosine similarity vector-based approach measures similar two texts based word frequency. texts represented word frequency vectors, similarity computed cosine angle vectors: cos(θ) = (. B) / |||| ||B|| : B word frequency vectors. . dot product. |||| ||B|| vector magnitudes (lengths). Interpretation: Ranges 0 (completely different) 1 (identical). Takes word frequency account, word appears multiple times texts, similarity score higher. Ignores word order.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: Definition: Levenshtein distance (edit distance) measures number single-character edits (insertions, deletions, substitutions) required transform one text another. Interpretation: lower value means texts similar. score 0 means texts identical. Unlike Jaccard Cosine similarity, method sensitive word order spelling differences.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: Definition: LCS measures longest sequence characters (necessarily consecutive) appears texts order. Interpretation: Higher values indicate similarity. Unlike Levenshtein, LCS count insertions/deletions break order characters. Good detecting similar sentence structures.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
text: deduplication, combination Jaccard + Cosine Similarity works well. cases word order matters, use Levenshtein LCS.

title: Compare Two Blocks of Text — compare_texts
code: compare_texts("This is a test", "This is a test") #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘stringdist’ compare_texts("This is a test", "This is a different test") #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘stringdist’

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- data.frame( x = rep(1:5, each = 3), y = rnorm(15), group = rep(letters[1:5], times = 3) ) library(tidyverse) ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y, colour = group)) + geom_point(size = 4) + scale_color_manual(values = juno_palette()) + theme_minimal() } # }

what: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
title: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
text: function creates horizontal stacked bar chart (like one used systematic review. designed visualize categorical appraisal CEESTAT results (e.g., Gold, Green, Amber, Red, N/) across multiple review criteria.

title: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
code: plot_CEESTAT(   df,   palette = c(Gold = "#b28800", Green = "#00a651", Amber = "#f7931e", Red = "#c1272d",     NA_ = "#fbe8b5") )

title: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
text: df data frame one column Question (character) additional columns appraisal category (e.g., Gold, Green, Amber, Red, NA_), numeric. palette named vector colors appraisal category. Defaults standard color set used systematic review plots.

title: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
text: ggplot object representing horizontal stacked bar chart.

title: Plot a horizontal stacked bar chart for review assessments — plot_CEESTAT
code: review_data <- data.frame(   Question = c(     "Is the review question clear?",     "Is there a protocol?",     "Is the search clearly defined?",     "Is the search comprehensive?",     "Are eligibility criteria clearly defined?",     "Is eligibility criteria consistently applied?",     "Are eligibility decisions transparently reported?",     "Was each study critically appraised?",     "During critical appraisal was effort made to minimize subjectivity?",     "Is the method of data extraction fully documented?",     "Are the extracted data reported for each study?",     "Were extracted data cross checked by more than one reviewer?",     "Is the choice of synthesis approach appropriate?",     "Is a statistical estimate of pooled effect (or similar) provided together with a measure of precision?",     "Is variability in the study findings investigated and discussed?",     "Have limitations of the synthesis been considered?"   ),   Gold = c(50, 30, 35, 34, 42, 40, 39, 32, 33, 37, 33, 32, 34, 20, 25, 28),   Green = c(8, 10, 8, 9, 9, 6, 6, 5, 1, 10, 13, 10, 12, 5, 12, 10),   Amber = c(0, 10, 9, 9, 3, 4, 5, 5, 1, 2, 3, 1, 6, 3, 5, 8),   Red = c(0, 5, 5, 4, 1, 4, 4, 7, 14, 3, 1, 10, 3, 1, 2, 5),   NA_ = c(0, 0, 0, 2, 0, 1, 2, 1, 9, 1, 2, 5, 0, 10, 10, 4) )  plot_CEESTAT(review_data)
